When I say that the purpose is to deter crime, it is important to take the next step and ask oneself: what is the purpose of deterring crime. Well, it is to make society safe. Obviously, if we only consider "deterring crime" we can justify life in prison for any tiny infraction. However, this would not fulfill the role of making society safe (the purpose of deterring crime), because we all know that everyone commits minor infractions all the time. Hence, the overarching purpose of deterring crime does not automatically suppose that any crime can receive any punishment, because its purpose would not be fulfilled.
 
 Rehabilitation is a very difficult key function to justify because there are no standards for knowing when a person is rehabilitated. This is why, when it happens, it is good, but we can never really make this a centerpiece purpose of our justice system.

Depending on your perspective, the justice system attempts to accomplish a variety of goals. Ideally, our justice system is to hold people accountable for their actions and provide appropriate punishment to offenders for the sake of victims. However, as one who works in and extensively studies the justice system, my perspective is that our current justice system intends to "get tough" on criminals. This movement has existed for the past 25-30 years, and potentially will continue until the political pendulum sways to the other side. In theory and in practice, deterrence does not keep people from committing crimes. It sounds good, but it really doesn't work. Rehabilitation was a significant aspect of our justice system for most of the 20th century until the mid-1970s; the establishment of the "get tough" movement. Punishment is always going to be a central part of the justice system, but the type of philosophy that drives it will alter. Realistically, our justice system criminalizes offenders, which has led to mass imprisonment, drastic changes in drug, sex offender, and terrorist laws, and various disparities and a disproportion of minorities caught up in the system. Conservatives may disagree, but criminologists will not dispute!

 The problem is not criminalizing offenders. Instead it has to do with the sentencing policies. .....A first time non-violent drug offender (who can be rehabilitated) gets a 3-15 year sentence.....Meanwhile in the same court a pedophile (who CANNOT be rehabilitated) gets 6 mos-1yr......now it does not take a rocket scientist or even a criminologist to see that something is terribly wrong with this picture..........No one is saying that certain crimes should be legalized.....you miss the point..........When speaking from a criminologist point of view the actual crime it not what is important....instead we look at what CAUSED the offender to commit the crime, how can we change the system and change the social conditions so that the crime rates actually drop. Punishment is meant to deter crime.....it is not difficult to see that this policy is not working. ......I am not bashing the system....I am just saying that there are some major problems with it.

 You say the primary goal of justice is to deter crime. That is a very arguable opinion. There are many other philosophies of punishment that the American justice system commonly employs, such as retribution, restitution, and incarceration. I would argue that it's not just one philosophy that serves as the primary goal, but multiple philosophies. That is one reason for its complexity.
 
 There are other statements that you made that shows you have a sensible understanding of the justice system. You're right, it is a business! For example, have you ever attended the American Correctional Association's annual meeting? I have not, but I have heard that it's nothing more than a large venue for private business marketing. 
 
 Also, I agree with you in regards to the racism issue in that there are other factors at play here. Maybe I made too bold of statements previously. Socio-economic conditions and geographical locations also play a role. However, my point is we know that the people who live in the urban, impoverished areas of cities, where a lot of street crimes are committed, are mainly minorities. Unfortunately, a lot of children grow up in a primary social environment that condones crime. 
 
 Lastly, c'mon now, we all know that not every offender receives due process rights as the book states they should. People make mistakes, even judges and lawyers. The issue is that the people who have mistakes in their judicial proceedings don't have the appropriate resources to help advocate the appeal process. Yes, there are some advocacy groups that help inmates file for appeals in their cases, and inmates help one another in prison (e.g., jailhouse lawyers). However, we know that many litigation cases are not won in defense for the inmates (2% success rate). In my opinion, I believe the system is too prideful at times to admit to mistakes.
